fields.title: How to install python 3.8 manually in ubuntu linux
fields.content:
Difficulty - Very Easy

Steps:

1.Download tarball from https://www.python.org/ftp/python/3.8.0/Python-3.8.0.tgz (official link)

 

2.Extract the tarball by right clicking on file and selecting extract here.

 

3.Right click on extracted folder and choose open in terminal .

 

4.Type

./configure

if you recieve error like

zipimport.ZipImportError: can't decompress data; zlib not available

you need to install zlib by

sudo apt install zlib1g-dev

 

5.Type the following to finish installation it may take sometime -

sudo make

sudo make install

 

Now check the python version by typing python3 -V

Done.

fields.title: How to enable night light in ubuntu
fields.content:
Its very easy to enable night mode from setting but lets build a shortcut so that we don't have to go through all the trouble again and again

lets bind this command to a key-

Terminal:

gsettings set org.gnome.settings-daemon.plugins.color night-light-enabled true

Steps

1.Click on all applications button type keyboard shortcut in search move to bottom of that page

2.Click on + button under custom shortcuts

Give it a name and in command box type:

gsettings set org.gnome.settings-daemon.plugins.color night-light-enabled true

Then click on assign shortcut and choose your keys you want to assign this function to like Alt+L.

 

Now try it out, also you can add another shortcut to disable night light by setting above command to false and assigning it another keyset.

fields.title: Big O notations
fields.content:
Big O notation describes how quickly the runtime will grow relative to input as it gets arbitrarily large

, also called as asymptotic notation.

We want to compare the growth in runtime as the input size grows not the actual runtime of algo

As the input grows very large we only worry about the terms that grow the fastest ie constants will be mostly dropped as  they become insignificant

in short

As the workload of your job goes up, how much longer does it take to complete it?

 

Big O is useful to compare how well two algorithms will scale up as the size of inputs is increased.

various examples of big o runtimes are

 

Constant or O(1):

def const(n):
   print(n[0])
arr=[1,2,3,4]
const(arr)

 

Linear or O(n):

arr=[1,2,3,4,5]
for var in arr:
   print(var)

in this case  print will scale with n linearly ie it will print n items n times

 

Quadratic or n^2:

def quad(arr):
   for one in arr:
      for two in arr:
         print(one,two)
lst=[1,2,3,4]
quad(lst)

can you guess the output it will need to perform n times for n items ie n*2  or 4^2 will will result in 16 operations here.

in short-

  • O(n): If input size is doubled the runtime doubles

  • O(n2): If the input size doubles the runtime quadruples

  • O(log n): If the input size doubles the runtime increases by one

  • O(2n): If the input size increases by one, the runtime doubles

  • O(N Log N) - Time to complete increases by the number of items times the result of Log2(N). An example of this is heap sort and quick sort

  • O(N!) - Time to complete is the factorial of the input set. An example of this is the traveling salesman problem brute-force solution.

fields.title: How to fix grub/ubuntu not loading while dual booting
fields.content:
After trying out everything are you still unable to properly dual boot ubuntu alongside windows

Here is probably the last solution that will most probably fix out your problems

and its very simple

Terminal:

sudo apt-add-repository ppa:yannubuntu/boot-repair

sudo apt-get update

sudo apt-get install -y boot-repair

boot-repair

Voila restart and see it working.

Don't forget to run this command in Windows

CommandPrompt(admin)

bcdedit /set {bootmgr} path \EFI\ubuntu\shimx64.efi

fields.title: How to disable/block website in ubuntu
fields.content:
Everyone understand the pain of getting lost while opening laptop for working/studying

So we must take a resolve and block unwanted distractions to keep up our productivity intact

Ubuntu terminal:

sudo nano etc/hosts

now add lines to route those webpages you want to block to 0.0.0.0 so they become inacessible

0.0.0.0 facebook.com
0.0.0.0 youtube.com

and enjoy the task in hand peacefully!

fields.title: Factorial in python
fields.content:
Factorial is multiplication of all non negative integers smaller than or equal to number.

For example factorial of 4 is 4*3*2*1 which is 120.

Using recursion

def factorial(n): 

    return 1 if n==1 else n * factorial(n - 1);  

num = 4; 
print("Factorial of->",num,"is->", 
factorial(num))

 

using while loop:

n=int(input())
fact=1
while n>0:
    
    fact=fact*n
    n=n-1
print(fact)

fields.title: Fibonacci using recursion python
fields.content:
The Fibonacci numbers integers in  sequence-

0, 1, 1, 2, 3, 5, 8, 13, 21

Mathematically can be written as

  Fn = Fn-1 + Fn-2

Implementation using recursion in python

def Fibonacci(num): 
    if n<0: 
        print("Enter positive integer") 
    #Base cases
    elif num==1: 
        return 0
    elif num==2: 
        return 1
    else: 
        return Fibonacci(num-1)+Fibonacci(num-2) 
print(Fibonacci(10))

OR

def fibo(num):
    return num if num<=1 else fibo(num-1)+fibo(num-2)
num=10
for num in range(num):
    print(fibo(num))

 

Using for loop

def fibonacci(n): 
    a = 0
    b = 1
    if n < 0: 
        print("Enter positive number") 
    elif n == 0: 
        return a 
    elif n == 1: 
        return b 
    else: 
        for i in range(2,n): 
            c = a + b 
            a = b 
            b = c 
        return b 
  print(fibonacci(10))

 

 

 

 

.

fields.title: Recover lost data in jupyter notebook
fields.content:
Recently i faced a very breathtaking error due to xrf not loaded in jupyter

If you have also lost data in jupyter notebook due to some errors don't worry you have reached right place

Open jupyter notebook and type:

%history -g

And guess what it has log of all the commands you executed Handy save.

you can also export to plain text file using:

%history -g -f mylostdata

fields.title: Basic Maths for Machine learning intro-1
fields.content:
Distance

Distance of a point P(x,y) from the origin is given by d(0;P)=√x2+y2.[Pythagoras]

Distance between two points P(x1;y1) and Q(x2;y2) is given by:

d(P;Q)=√ p(x2−x1)2+(y2−y1)2

 

Slope intercept equation - A linear equation of the form y = mx + c where m is the slope of the line and c is the coordinate for the y term of the y-intercept.

Vector

A vector is an object that has a magnitude and a direction. It can be represented as a directed line segment, whose length is the magnitude of the vector and with an arrow indicating the direction. The direction of the vector is from its tail to its head.

The dot product between two vectors is based on the projection of one vector onto another.

a⋅b=|a|⋅|b|⋅cosθ 

Angle between two vectors:

cos α =  a·b
|a|·|b|

STATS

A probability density function f(x) is a function that is used to find the probabilities of a continuous variable across a range of values.

It tells us what the shape of the probability distribution is.

 

Normal distribution

The normal distribution is called normal because it’s seen as an ideal. It’s what we “normally” expect to see in real life for a lot of continuous data such as measurements of heights weights etc.

The probability density decreases the further away we get from the mean.

The normal distribution is defined by two parameters, μ and σ 2 .

μ tells you where the center of the curve is, and σ gives you the spread.

If a continuous random variable X follows a normal distribution with mean μ and standard deviation σ, this is generally written X ~ N(μ, σ 2 ).

The general formula for the probability density function of the normal distribution is

\(f(x) = \frac{e^{-(x - \mu)^{2}/(2\sigma^{2}) }} {\sigma\sqrt{2\pi}}\)

The case where μ = 0 and σ = 1 is called the standard normal distribution. The equation for the standard normal distribution is

\(f(x) = \frac{e^{-x^{2}/2}} {\sqrt{2\pi}}\)

 

Now what normal distribution is basically:

The Normal Distribution has mean = median = mode,symmetry about the center, 50% of values less than the mean and 50% greater than the mean

The Standard Deviation is a measure of how spread out data is.

It follows 68:95:99 rules ie -68% of values are within 1 standard deviation  of the mean ,95% of values are within 2 SD of the mean and 99.7% of values are within 3SD  of the mean

 

Z Score

z-score is the number of standard deviations from the mean a data point is.

A z-score is also known as a standard score and it can be placed on a normal distribution curve. Z-scores range from -3 SD  to +3 SD.

formula:     z = (x – μ) / σ

Standardization is the process of transforming a variable to one with a mean of 0 and a SD of 1.

Kernel density estimation

KDE is a way to estimate the probability density function(PDF) of a random variable. Kernel density estimation is a fundamental data smoothing problem where inferences about the population are made, based on a finite data sample.

Sampling Distribution

A sampling distribution can be thought of as a relative frequency distribution with a very large number of samples or as a relative frequency distribution approaches the sampling distribution as the number of samples approaches infinity. When a variable is discrete, the heights of the distribution are probabilities. When a variable is continuous, the class intervals have no width and and the heights of the distribution are probability densities.

Each sample has its own sample mean and the distribution of the sample means is known as the sample distribution.

The standard deviation of a sampling distribution is called the standard error.

Central Limit Theorem

It states that the sampling distribution of the mean of any independent, random variable will be normal or nearly normal, if the sample size is large enough.

CLT is a statistical theory stating that given a sufficiently large sample size from a population with a finite level of variance, the mean of all samples from the same population will be approximately equal to the mean of the population.

As a general rule, sample sizes equal to or greater than 30 are deemed sufficient to show that the distribution of the sample means is fairly normally distributed.A sufficiently large sample size can predict the characteristics of a population accurately.

Thus, as the sample size (N) increases the sampling error will decrease.

**.-The theorem states that as the size of the sample increases, the distribution of the mean across multiple samples will approximate a Gaussian distribution.

To be continued....

fields.title: Cannot access aws ec2 using ssh after enabling ufw
fields.content:
After enabling ufw for some reason you got locked out of your own EC2 server ,don't worry you don't have to delete your instance

this is a pretty fix and most easiest one which i found after searching for hours and this is courtesy of stackexchange-

Goto your ec2 console ie webpage find instance right click on it and

 1.Open view/change user data in instance settings.
 2. Add the script(mentioned below) and save it.

bootcmd:
- cloud-init-per always fix_broken_ufw_1 sh -xc "/usr/sbin/service ufw stop >> /var/tmp/svc_$INSTANCE_ID 2>&1 || true" 
- cloud-init-per always fix_broken_ufw_2 sh -xc "/usr/sbin/ufw disable>> /var/tmp/ufw_$INSTANCE_ID 2>&1 || true"

fields.title: List all pip packages
fields.content:
Many times we lose track of what packages were installed and obviously we want to remove unused packages form our virtual environment the simplest command that list all packeages is:

pip search *

fields.title: Django how to migrate/move or backup data from server to new server
fields.content:
Easiest way to move data from django is to use builin dump data command

./manage.py dumpdata > backup.json

this will create a backup.json in your current directory now all you need to use this data is new server having same models is just type:

./manage.py loaddata backup.json

We can choose specific  models even app from which we want to export data

./manage.py dumpdata appname > app.json
or 
./manage.py dumpdata blog.models > blog.json
